div.head:
Embleme 50. Of the Secrets of Nature.
The Dragon kills the woman, and shee him, and are both bloody
all over.

lg.l: Fitt for the Dragon digge a cavous place,
And therewith joyne the woman face to face:
Whilst hee the joyes of weelocke reaps, shee dyes,
With whome entomb him, that hee may not rise;
This is hee killd, and ting'd with blood all o're:
Take but this course, and you need aske noe more

div.head: Discourse 50.
div.ab:
The mansion of Dragons is in caverns of the earth, but the residence
of men above the earth in the imediate aire; which two Elements
are contrary, and appointed by the Philosophers to be joynd together,
that one may act upon the other: But by the woman others meane, as
Basill in Key 2d. sayth: For it is not convenient or comodious for an-
Eagle to place her nest upon the Alps, because her chickens would dye
through the coldnesse of the Snow at the top of the mountains: But
if you add to the Eagle a cold Dragon, which hath had his habitation
a long time in the rocks, and crept out of the caves of the earth,-
and put them both into an infernall sell, then will Pluto blow a-
blast, and draw a volatile fiery spirit out of the cold dragon, which
with its great heat will burne the Eagles feathers, and excite such a
sudorificke bath, as to melt the Snow at the top of the mountains,-
and turne it into water; from which a minerable bath may be well-
præpared, contributing fortune and health to the King. Admirable in
deed it is, that a cold dragon should yeild a fiery Spirit; yet experience-
declares it to be true in burned serpents, which doe send forth a venomous-
flame poysoning the standers by: Nor in vayne are the keepers of the Chy
micall treasures called flammivomous dragons, as the keepers of the golden
fleece, the Hesperian gardens, Cadmus, and the like. But this dragon lives
in streight places of subterranean rocks, which you must there take, and
joyne to the Eagle or woman, to her, in the grave, to the other, if you-
had rather, in the nest: For the nature of a dragon is sometimes to lye in
waite for the Eagles eggs, and wage mortall warre with the Eagle: Some
there are of the Græcian writers who affirme that a dragon in times past-
fell in love with a mayd and lay with her. What wonder therefore, if
the Philosophers would have their dragon shutt up in a caverne with a-
woman? Greverus joynes red and blacke dragons together in the deep-
gulfe of the mountaine, and burnes them with fire, and the blacke pe
rishing, hee sayth that the keeper of the mountaine searcheth for them
every where, and brings them to the mountaine. Merlin in his vision (if it
be not suppositious) makes mention of a white and red dragon; These
Dragons, whatsoever they be, whether one be a woman, or a female-
dragon, doe act one with the other, till they both dye, and emitt blood
from their wounds, wherewith they are embrued. But here the element
of earth and fire is understood by the dragon, and by the woman the
element of aire and water; whereupon sayth Clangor buccinæ: The Dragon
is the matter remaining in the bottome after the water be distilld from
it: And according to Hermes: The water of aire being between heaven and
earth is the life of every thing, for that water dissolves a body into a-
Discourse 50.
spirit, and vivifyes a dead thing, and makes matrimony between man and wo
man: For it conferrs the whole benefitt of the art: Of the earth allso hee thus
speaks. And moreover understand, that the particular earth, which wee tread
upon, is not the true element, yea is elemented with its true fifth element: Nor
doth the fifth elementall substance recede from its elemented body, of which
the earth is formed. And a little after. But the Virgin and true element,-
which fire cannot burne, is in the center of the earth: This is the dragon,
whereof wee speake, insinuating itselfe even into the center of the earth,
where the heat being great, it conceives within itselfe a flaming heat, where
with it burnes the woman or eagle. The woman or eagle is indeed an airy-
water, which some call the white or cælestiall eagle, and will have it made
of comon Mercury, or sublimed Salts, following therein the sense of some cer
taine men blind in this art, faigning themselves to be quicksighted; But-
sayth Count Bernhard in his Epistle, I tell you truely, that noe water dissolves
a metallicke species by naturall reduction, except that which continues with-
it in matter and forme, and which the metalls themselves can recongeale:-
And a little after: Nor doth that water appertaine to bodyes in solutions, which
remains not with them in congelations: And a little after: I tell you truely,
that the oyle which naturally incerates and joyns natures together, and natu
rally introduceth a Medicine for the tinging of other bodyes, is not compounded
of any other extraneous thing, but onely of the bowells of the body which is
to be dissolved: This therefore being apprehended, the eagle and woman, as
allso the Dragon with the secrets of allmost the whole art are understood,-
which perhaps wee have thus farre too openly explained and declared to
the Sonns of learning, that God may hereby be glorifyed. . . . .
